top_comment.text:
I am a researcher involved in biological research. I'll tell you, most of 
the path breaking research with leads ultimately to development of drugs is 
done by public money, in public funded Research institutes. Scientists in 
Universities or research institutes who are funded with public money 
discover the genes and drug targets involved in diseases. Only after much 
research and knowledge has been generated with public money, then the 
companies jump into "discovering" drugs or treatments, and charge hefty 
sums of money. 

EXAMPLE: Take the Example of BRCA gene involved in cancer. Mary Claire King 
working in a University first discovered that BRCA gene mutations are 
involved in Majority of Breast cancers. After this important and original 
discovery, funded with public money, The company Myriad, cloned and found 
many mutations and patented them, making the diagnostic use of BRCA 
mutations in cancer costlier. So, Most of the times the lead is provided by 
public funded Research which the companies take and develop into 
therapeutics or diagnostics. They have no ethical rights to charge 
insanely. 

RMEMBER: The driving force behind all therapeutic research and discoveries 
is the public funded BASIC research, the fruits of which companies reap. ﻿

comments.text:
+Jan Koren
Intellectual property rights are safeguarded in practically every country.

May be not china but the point holds.

So India has a law in case the patent has to be by passed.

It was put in place which sets up upper and lower limits of royalty to be 
paid.

Now the medicine developed has no alternatives and is for the worst case 
scenario that makes it a high value drug.

So the pharma companies in India can initiate a court process which will 
open a competetive bid in which they will enter a price in which they will 
cover all there costs and royalties for the product.

The only constraint is that the revenue of the drug will be taken as the 
dividing amount.

So say the Indian company quotes price for 100 dollars then Indian side 
gets only three dollars for all there operations and they have to pay the 
american company 97 dollars.

Say the Indian company does business for the drug worth a million dollars.

They will pay the american company 32 million for the research they did.

The american company is getting paid without spending a penny to introduce 
or market the drug in a foreign country.

comments.text:
Really now? How does the current system encourage such an apparently 
wonderous level of "pace or advancement"?

So a company like Bayer can develop a drug (often by stealing remedies from 
remote civilisations), and then get an absolute global monopoly on it for 
20 or more years and nobody else in the world can make or sell anything 
even remotely similar for this period, and they can hence charge whatever 
the hell they like, with effectively nothing going to the people who 
actually made the drug, but all of the profits (coming from a corporate 
enforced global monopoly) going straight to the shareholders. 

What incentive is there to develop something better when you have a legally 
enforced monopoly that's preventing any competition? The industrial 
revolution was held back for decades because the inventor of the steam 
engine got his rich buddies to bend the law into his favour, patented his 
engine, and spent ten years forcing people to pay licenses to him whilst 
doing nothing to innovate and destroying anyone who dared compete. 
Ironically he tried to improve his design, only to find he couldn't because 
his new design had already been patented by someone else who was exploiting 
the same system he created in the same way he intended it to work. What we 
have today is a thousand times more obscene, and is enforced on a global 
scale.

comments.text:
There's advantages and disadvantages.  For example, I just started a 
business and don't have a very big budget.  Now, I'm thinking about getting 
a patent for my innovation, but patents can cost over 25k to get, depending 
on the nature of what's being patented.  Given my innovation could be made 
by any big company for cheaper and on a bigger scale, I wouldn't stand a 
competitive chance without it.  So getting patents, or at least a 
provisional patent, allows small businesses free space to develop and 
compete with the big dogs.  

On the other hand though, there's patent trolls, who simply patent things 
without ever making anything.  They do this to either block out 
competition, sue companies for infringement, or sell them.  This makes the 
patent itself the business and not the product.  

As with everything, there's reasons why it exists and ways people can 
exploit it.  My hero, Tesla, never patented any of his great inventions 
because he wanted the whole world to benefit.  That's the way it should be, 
but with the money system in place most people don't have that luxury.

comments.text:
+Kuba022 The concept of stealing ideas isn't new. The only thing rather 
"new" about it is the fact that it can be prosecuted by law, which is a 
cultural accomplishment. It allowed people to take huge financial risks 
(opportunities) without fearing the consequence of being thrown under the

know how it is stealing under the current system. Do people have to 
involuntarily give their resources and property away other than by paying 
taxes? Because I pretty much thought of that as the sheer definition of 
"stealing". One could debate how our banking system might include elements 
of stealing but remember we're talking about pharmaceutical companies here.

I used to have a similar stance on intellectual property until I actually 
got to know "small" musicians and producers who literally get eaten up by 
the big record companies because their intellectual property is stolen by 
an internet generation that somehow feels entitled to get everything for 
free and therefore destroys their source of income. You could argue that it 
might be the fault of greedy big record companies but reality is (and 
that's what those "small" musicians say) they don't have the least chance 
of competing against the big fish when their intellectual property is 
notoriously stolen and the market is being reduced to an oligopoly. And 
guess who can afford the better lawyers?

What do you think would happen if you simply did away with patents? If 
anybody survived, it would be the big companies you seem to dislike so 
much. Adding insult to injury you would reward theft of intellectual 
property as companies who haven't spent a dime on research are able to sell 
the product to a much lower price - potentially eradicating the actually 
research-intensive players on the market and killing any incentive for 
undertaking the risk of innovation again.

How exactly did universities sell their ideas without labelling it as 
"intellectual property" I wonder? To me that notion seems really 
contradictory. If it weren't property, what would there be to sell? And how 
would that be any different from patents?
comments.author: hallabalooza

comments.text:
+hallabalooza Your "sneak around and steal" rhetoric isn't really fair. 
It's only "stealing" under the current system, which I think is wrong, 
unfair and deeply immoral. The concept of "stealing ideas" in itself is a 
relatively new invention and it's completely artificial.

Universities (and people in general) were making money with their ideas 
long before they could patent them. People were inventing stuff even before 
they had this "incentive" you talk about. When anyone could "steal" their 
idea and freely improve upon it.

And notice, that I'm not for removing this incentive altogether, just 
reducing it to a workable size. Decades-long patent protections are 
ridiculous. They are stifling innovation and artificially inflate prices.

My "two year estimate" isn't designed to balance out current development 
programs. Current development programs are not covered by future profits, 
but by current profits. These companies develop new things with the money 
they have, not with the money they hope to have. They do not operate at a 
loss and would not operate at a loss, even if cut the patent protection to 
two months. They would simply have to re-adjust to a new variable and 
re-evaluate their policies, but they would suffer no immediate loss.

I think a two-year protection is more than fair. It's long enough to 
establish your market position and build an advantage in any field, and yet 
it allows others to start improving the idea relatively quickly. It doesn't 
kill the competition and more importantly it doesn't kill as many people.
comments.author: Kuba022

comments.text:
You're living in a dream world - I'm living in reality that's the 
difference. I don't say I wholeheartedly support the system but I 
understand why your criticism is pointless utopia.

First off, yes competition drives innovation, but how would there be 
competition without any incentive. What is the incentive of any corporation 
or of any person for that matter to invest tons of money and resources in 
the development of a pharmaceutical drug if somebody could just sneak 
around the corner and steal the idea, only to sell it for a ridiculous 
price. That is NOT what drives innovation, it is stealing. I invested 
resources and someone else (who has not invested and taken the risk) gets 
the price - simple as that.

You're claiming you don't have an incentive to develop a new product when 
another company sits on the patent, but I bet you don't have the least 
evidence to support that hypothesis. If you think logically, why would the 
incentive of another company to develop a competitive product just vanish? 
When Pfizer had the patent for viagra, Bayer invented levitra - they didn't 
just lean back and stop innovating - quite the contrary. It gave them the 
confidence to develop a competitive product entirely on their own without 
stealing any intellectual property.

I agree that the idea of having a high profit margin in the years holding 
the patent might sound inhuman and I can understand that some people will 
even consider it "murder". But you can't just fully replace rational 
thinking with irrational emotions and claim a monopoly on morality. That's 
why I call it utopia. I know that many times companies would "buy out"

comments.text:
+hallabalooza 
"Steal"? I think you are confusing the terms. 

Competition is what drives development. That's what it was for the majority 
of human history. Someone came up with a good idea, started to sell a 
product, made some money on it, established a brand. Then other people 
tried to make a similar product, improve it, make it better, make it 
cheaper, make it more accessible. And it was all good for everyone.

Now, if you as a pharmaceutical company are allowed to sit on a patent, you 
don't really have a strong motivation to develop a better cure. Why would 
you? You are the only one with the product, and you are allowed to rip off 
those who are dying. Nobody else is allowed to help them and they have the 
strongest motivation to pay whatever outlandish amount of money you demand. 
They will sell their cars, their houses, anything for a chance to 
survive. THIS is stealing. Actually it's worse. It's murder.

And kleptocracy is a system in which a ruling class increases its own 
 wealth at the expense of the wider population often with pretense of 
honest service. Newsflash: the ruling class in the USA are the banks and 
the corporations, with their cronies in the House. Kleptocracy is already 
here and our current patent system is a huge part of it, building a wall 
between the rich and the regular people.

By the way, some of the patents are bought from the regular people, bought 
from universities and from those who actually developed them. And quite 
often they are bought on the cheap. It also sometimes happens that big 
companies force people to give up their rights and don't give a fuck about 
actual inventors. Anything to get your hands on this golden cow with a 
patent number stamped on its forehead. This system is sick and to be 
honest, you are sick for supporting it.

top_comment.text:
Well, first of all, the full quote appears to be:
“Is this going to have a big effect on our business model?” Dekkers said 
Dec. 3 at a conference in London. “No, because we did not develop this 
product for the Indian market, let’s be honest. We developed this product 
for Western patients who can afford this product, quite honestly. It is an 
expensive product, being an oncology product.”
from 
http://www.businessweek.com/news/2014-01-21/merck-to-bristol-myers-face-more-threats-on-india-drug-patents#p2

So apparently it was a statement to calm shareholders that Bayer would 
still make profits in spite of the losses on the Indian market due to 
compulsory licenses.
The real question, however, is what price we (as humanity) affix to 
intellectual property and innovation.   It's a drug that has been developed 
at a cost to the company and to the countries in which that company does 
research (presumably Germany for Bayer) and now India comes along and is 
essentially taking away the compensation for that development (which is not 
to say that the price Bayer put on the drug is a fair compensation).

 There are other companies (see the businessweek link above) like Merck 
etc. that have e.g. HIV drugs, which may be looking at the same situation.  
As far as I understand it, the Indian authorities can only award a 
compulsory license to an alternative manufacturer if the medicine is 
patented in India.  So it might backfire in such a way that companies will 
no longer patent (and manufacture and sell) certain highly priced 
medication in India.  On the other hand it may also lead to companies 
reconsidering their pricing policies.  But let's face it:  drug development 
and synthesis are darn expensive.

+The Young Turks  It would not hurt much to have a bit more balanced a 
perspective on the subject matter and elucidate the conflicts at work here, 
but it's not all black and white.﻿

This shit is so fucking obvious, forget the recouping investment, all the 
RD, Vaccines and cures for fatal illness should be done for altruism, and 
if it's not, then YES, should be forced to be. How's this. Instead of 
complaining they're having their property stolen... instead of worrying 
about middle class share holders and execs insane bonuses, they seek to be

Salk to see how it's done. If they are not willing to follow the 
traditional esteemed tenets of Alturism implied for centuries in the 
medical profession, fuck them. Force them. Anyone who says 'They'll just 
stop research' let me paint you this picture... lets put the proverbial 
horses head in their collective beds... 'Listen, since we're a Fed. Govt.. 
of a Sovereign state, and you're in our masters, AKA the people's... 
house.. what you're going to do, is be free to make all the money you want 
off medication for non-fatal conditions, but the ones you make for cancer, 
malaria, AIDS and the like... you sell at a loss, or we nationalize you, 
seize your research and make it a state priority to disseminate your 
medication globally at a reduced price, now you can move over seas, but you 
wont make the cash you are allowed in Western capitalist democracies on all 
your other medications, chose".... anyone who doesn't think that's fair, go 
live in the free and unregulated Utopia's of Somalia or South Sudan.﻿

comments.author: Apis4

comments.text:
I agree completely. The system is just plain broken... and I think it could 
be brought to its knees through black markets. If you make, say, $30k a 
year, and you can't possibly afford this drug which you need to live, why 
on earth would you not buy it from any possible source? To what length 
would you *not* go to get it?

Another thing that crosses my mind is how hard it might be to actually make 
it yourself. We know this drug is basically marked up 100-fold and doesn't 
cost much to produce - if it's so cheap to make, maybe some resourceful 
people could make it themselves.
